I took a minute. Senator Guilfoyle took 59 seconds. Senator Durack took 1 minute 13 seconds and Senator Carrick took 1 minute 7 seconds. It is rather interesting when we break it down and take an average as a statistical exercise. This may all sound very interesting but I invite honourable senators to study tomorrow the 2 tables which I hope the Senate will give me leave to incorporate. I must say, Mr President, that as one who sits listening through question time day after day I would have thought that on balance answers tended to be a lot longer than the questions asked. But to my surprise with an average of 108 words per question and 145 words per answer there is not such a great gap. On average it takes 44 seconds to ask a question and only 62 seconds to answer it.
- If you know anything about journalism you know that that is a bloody long time.

-I looked up in the chamber one day- I do not know whether Senator Douglas McClelland was speaking- and I was almost going to raise a point of order and say to the Clerk: 'Surely that clock must be stopped up there. It shows only 5 minutes has passed and it seems about 5 hours'.
- It is merely 50 per cent longer.
- Wait a minute. We are talking about 44 seconds and 62 seconds. I was going to say that one gets the general impression here that answers are very much longer than questions.
- They are.
- They are not that much longer.
- If you take into consideration that Senator Cotton says yes or no and, as happened today, Senator Webster said yes to one question.

- Yes, and I have taken into consideration that some people ask questions that take a very long time. Some questions give an enormous amount of information. I have heard questions asked here that I thought sounded almost like adjournment speeches. We get some very long questions at times. I thought that just as a matter of intellectual interest to honourable senators the tables should be prepared. The first table shows the breakup of the time used in the Senate over a range of matters such as motions of condolence, Budget debates, question time, urgency debates, general business, legislation, etc. It is an interesting statistical breakdown. I must say that I found it of a great deal of interest.
- How much did it cost?

-It cost you nothing because I just never stop working. Mr President, I seek leave to incorporate these 2 tables in Hansard. I hope honourable senators find a great deal of interest in them. Maybe one night when we are not so tired we could have an adjournment debate lasting some hours.
-Is leave granted? There being no objection, leave is granted.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative. Senate adjourned at 11.45 p.m.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

subdebateinfo.title: Brisbane Airport: Environmental Impact Statement (Question No. 999)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Environment, Housing and Community Development, upon notice:

item.para: 1 ) Why has the environmental impact statement for the 1973 development of Brisbane airport not been published?
When is it likely that the statement will be published?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Environment, Housing and Community Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

item.para: 1 ) The need for improved airport facilities for Brisbane has been under consideration for some time and in 1 972 a Commonwealth-State-City Advisory Committee recommended that the airport should be developed on a site including land to the north and north-east of the existing airport. Associated with the Committee's investigation were extensive environmental studies by a technical committee comprising representatives from Commonwealth, State and local governments.

answer.para: Based on those studies the then Department of Civil Aviation prepared a document entitled 'Environmental Impact Statement for the Development of Brisbane Airport' March 1 973 as a report on the environmental aspects of the alternatives considered by the Advisory Committee and as part of a submission to the Government in 1 973.

Subsequently in September 1973 the then Minister for Transport directed the Bureau of Transport Economics to conduct an economic analysis of the alternative schemes for the development of Brisbane airport.
It was therefore decided that the public review of the environmental impact statement should be postponed pending the outcome of the Bureau of Transport Economics and consequential studies.

item.para: The Bureau of Transport Economics has completed its study and its report, which recommended that the existing runways be retained for as long as possible, was tabled in both Houses of Parliament on 7 April 1 976.

answer.para: It is understood that the Department of Transport is currently reviewing this matter with a view to advising the Government on a preferred long term development scheme. An environmental impact statement covering the preferred scheme will be prepared at the appropriate time and published in accordance with the requirements of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice:

item.para: 1 ) Are avocados being imported into Australia. If so, in what quantities and from which countries.
Who are the importers.
What action is taken to ensure that the imported fruit is completely free of disease.

talk.start.para: - The following information is provided in answer to the honourable senator's question:

item.para: 1 ) The Australian Statistician has advised that he cannot supply any information about imports of avocados because they are not recorded separately in overseas trade statistics.
The confidentiality provisions of the Census and Statistics Act 190S preclude the Statistician from supplying any information relating to individual importers.

The Department of Health has advised that imported avocado fruit is coming only from California, United States of America, provided the consignment is accompanied by a phytosanitary certificate endorsed 'This fruit is derived from a grove established from sources free of avocado sun blotch vims'. In addition the fruit is fumigated with methyl bromide and carefully inspected.

answer.para: Anti-cyclone Measures (Question No. 1128)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Science, upon notice:

item.para: 1 ) Have anti-cyclone measures been incorporated in new houses built in Darwin since cyclone Tracy. If so, how many of the houses are being built to withstand cyclones, and what degree of stress are they capable of withstanding.
Is the Department currently analysing the need for anti-cyclonic housing for regions most affected by cyclones, such as in Queensland, the Northern Territory and northern Western Australia.
Will the Minister provide details of such research and its current progress.

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable senator's questions is as follows:

quote.para: In respect of the honourable senator's questions, a reply was given on 6 October 1976 and appears on pages 1087-8 of Hansard.

answer.para: Defence: Technical Co-operation Program (Question No. 1132)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice:

item.para: Does the technical co-operation program between England, the United States of Am enc a, Canada and Australia contain a provision that a party to the Agreement need not disclose any information that the party does not in its national interest desire to disclose.
Under the Agreement, can parties have nationals operating in other countries, which are parties to the Agreement, without knowledge of that particular country.
Will the Minister make copies of the Agreement available.
Is there a similar agreement covering nuclear power.

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

item.para: Yes. The terms of reference of the various primary working groups within TTCP contain the words 'complete and continuous interchange of information . . . except as may be limited by national policy'.
No.

TTCP was established following an exchange of notes between the Governments of the United States, Britain and Canada in 1958. Australia joined the program in 1965 and was provided with the manual which defines the objectives, terms of reference and procedures of TTCP. The document is not freely available but arrangements could be made for the Senator to peruse a copy of the latest issue ( 1973) if he so desires.
We are not party to any similar agreement covering military research and development in nuclear power.

answer.para: Cape York and Arnhem Land: Wilderness Area (Question No. 1168) Senator Keeffe asked the Minister representing the Minister for Environment, Housing and Community Development, upon notice:

quote.para: Has the Government taken any steps to declare parts of, or all of, Cape York and Arnhem Land a wilderness area with full protection for all fauna and flora. If not, will the Government view this matter with immediate concern and a sense of urgency.

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Environment, Housing and Community Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

item.para: 1 ) Land in the Cape York area in Queensland is under the jurisdiction of that State.

Arnhem Land is scheduled for return to Aboriginal ownership under provisions of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Bill 1976. The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1 975 authorises the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service to assist and co-operate with Aboriginals in managing their land for nature conservation purposes. The Service will respond to any request for such assistance from the Aboriginals to whom ownership of Arnhem Land is transferred.

question.para: Welfare Services for the Aged (Question No. 1188)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice:

quote.para: Is the Minister aware that the Queensland Minister for Health, Dr L. Edwards, quoted in the Courier-Mail dated 3 October 1976, has expressed disappointment that the Commonwealth Government has reduced funds for welfare services for the aged. If so, (a) is the Commonwealth Government solely responsible for the Queensland Government's cutback in planned new programs for the aged foreshadowed by Dr Edwards, and (b) what new programs will be affected?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

quote.para: I am aware of the statement by Dr Edwards as reported in the Courier-Mail on 3 October 1976.

There has been no reduction in Commonwealth Government funds for aged persons' welfare. The honourable senator will be aware that I recently announced a $225m 3-year program for funding aged persons' homes projects. A sum of $45 m will be provided m 1976-77 and it is the Government 's objective to provide a further $ 1 80m over the following two years. In the meantime those organisations whose projects have been selected for funding in 1977-78 and 1978-79 may proceed with their projects using existing funds or bridging finance.

The Government has also announced a $ 12m, 3-year program to fund the construction of senior citizens' centres under the States Grants (Home Care) Act, i.e. $4m in each of the 3 years. Under this legislation this Government also reimburses two-thirds of State Government expenditure on home care services for aged persons, and two-thirds of the salaries paid to welfare officers. The amount allocated this financial year for these services has been increased to $1 1.7m, which is more than 28 per cent above the expenditure in 1975-76.

No new senior citizen projects can be approved this financial year because the outstanding expenditure at 30 June 1976 was in excess of $5. 5m and will require all the funds allocated. However, a total of $6m has been allocated for new projects in 1977-78 and 1978-79.

During 1975-76 home care services throughout the Commonwealth were extended considerably and it is now apparent that the $7m allocated for these services for this financial year, a 23 per cent increase on the amount provided in 1975-76, will be required to maintain existing services. Furthermore, due to increases in the salaries of welfare officers employed at senior citizens' centres, the $700,000 provided in 1976-77 will be required to fund the existing positions

As the honourable senator may be aware, the Government recently set up a Committee of Inquiry into Care of the Aged and Infirm and has also appointed a task force to examine welfare services and community based programs in the health/welfare/community development area. The States Grants (Home Care) Act is one of the programs under review.
Future policy decisions may be made in the light of the recommendations received, at which time an appropriate announcement will be made.

Therefore, in reply to (a) and (b) of the honourable senator's question, I can speak only of those services jointly funded under the States Grants (Home Care) Act and, as I have indicated, any new commitments will be dependent upon the decisions taken following consideration of the above Committee 's recommendations.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice:

item.para: 1 ) What is the average cost of construction per kilometre of bitumen sealed roads in Australia.
What is the average cost of construction per kilometre of sealed roads in Northern Australia, in particular, in places like the Kimberleys and the Cape.
Will the Government consider making additional grants for roads to these more remote regions so as to compensate for their higher construction, freight and wage costs.

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Transport has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

item.para: 1 ) Because of the wide variety of factors which influence the cost of road construction throughout Australia, such as terrain, standards for pavements and bridges, climatic conditions, materials availability etc., it is not meaningful to gather statistics to give an 'average' cost per kilometre for bitumen sealed roads except for particular roads.

As pointed out above, the cost of road construction varies markedly between regions. Some cost estimates in far north Australia which have recently come to my attention relate to the construction of the Perth to Darwin National Highway between Meek a thar a and Mt Newman in Western Australia ($64,000 per km), the Winton to Cloncurry section of the Landsborough Highway (National Highway) in Queensland ($98,000 per km), and the Cape River to Mt Douglas section of a beef road in Queensland ($1 10,000 per km).
The Commonwealth Government is providing grants to Queensland and Western Australia for roads under the National Roads Act and the Roads Grants Act.

answer.para: The grants being provided to each State were based generally on the recommendations made by the Bureau of Roads in its 'Report on Roads in Australia- 1973' which took into account the varying costs of road construction between regions when developing a warranted and feasible road program.

Since the Acts were introduced in 1974, the Commonwealth has provided additional grants to the States to generally offset the effects of cost increases. An additional $30m was provided in respect of 1 974-7S and this Government has provided further grants of $64m in respect of 1975-76 and $35. 8m for 1976-77 of which Queensland will receive $7.5m and Western Australia $4.6m.

subdebateinfo.title: Western Australia: State Shipping Service (Question No. 1202)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice:

item.para: Can the Minister explain the recent moves by the Western Australian Government to reduce the operations of State shipping to the north of that State.
What will be the effect of this reduction on the people of the north-west.

Do a lot of the problems associated with State sniping stem from the fact that in most instances there is no back loading. If so, could this problem be overcome if live cattle were allowed to be exported from the north-west of Western Australia.
Will the Minister, in conjunction with the Minister for Primary Industry, look into the viability of this project

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Transport has provided the following answers to the honourable member's question:

item.para: and (2) Apart from the withdrawal of Beroona from the North-west service in April this year I am not aware of any moves by the Western Australian State Government to further reduce the operations of State shipping to the north of the State.

and (4) I understand that the State Shipping Service has been operating at a loss for a number of years. In the circumstances I have no doubt that every opportunity of obtaining additional business would have been explored, including the shipment of live cattle.

answer.para: However, as the Service is operated by the Western Australian Coastal Shipping Commission which is responsible to the Western Australian Government, the honourable senator may wish to direct his question to the responsible authority.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Capital Territory Bus Service (Question No. 1207)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice:

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Capital Territory Bus Service (Question No. 1210)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice:

item.para: 1 ) What measures have been taken to assist handicapped persons using public transport in the Australian Capital Territory.
What special facilities are available on buses to assist handicapped persons wishing to use the public transport system in the Capital Territory.

talk.start.para: - The Minister for the Capital Territory has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

item.para: 1 ) and (2) Handicapped persons are in many categories and assistance to them on public transport presents significant design problems. Considerable research has been conducted overseas and measures have been taken to help handicapped people using rail systems but little of this experience can be translated to the operation of a bus service. People handicapped to the extent that they are confined to a wheel chair cannot conveniently use buses. Special transport, however, is available through the A.C.T. Health Services.

answer.para: For moderately handicapped people the general improvement in design of buses is of advantage to them.
Charter Aircraft: Use by Ministers and Members (Question No. 1214)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice:

item.para: 1 ) What rules apply to the use of charter aircraft by Ministers and/or members of Parliament before approval is given by the Minister.

Do any restrictions apply to additional passengers being carried on aircraft that are chartered by or on behalf of a Minister. If so, what categories of people are Ministers entitled to have accompany them on chartered aircraft flights which are a charge against the Commonwealth.

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

item.para: 1 ) Each case is considered on its merits. As a general rule I would approve charter flights by members for travel associated with the service of their electorates in circumstances where scheduled services are not available.

answer.para: In the case of Ministers and Opposition officer holders, approval is generally given to use charter aircraft where necessary to assist them to carry out the responsibilities of their offices in circumstances where commercial services are unavailable or would not allow commitments to be met.

The honourable senator will be aware that my approval is not required by those members of the House of Representatives and by the senators for the Northern Territory when using charter transport in accordance with their entitlement as determined by the Remuneration Tribunal (Clauses 2.22 to 2.24 of Determination No. 1976/6).

item.para: As a general rule Ministers may be accompanied by their spouse and members of personal staff (subject to the limitations on travel by ministerial staff). Travel by other persons is considered on the individual merits of each case having regard generally to need and any additional costs involved.

As the matter is currently before the Court it would be inappropriate for me to intervene at this stage. However when the prosecution has been finalised I will re-examine the matter in the light of any decision made by the Court

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice:

item.para: . What was the basis of the charges listed by the Peruvian authorities that caused the imprisonment of an Australian national, Miss Amanda Rees, in Lima.
What was the cause of the two months ' delay before the case was finalised.

talk.start.para: - The Foreign Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

item.para: The charge laid was 'illicit traffic in stupefying substances to the detriment of the State. '

The case has not yet been finalised. The examining magistrate ordered Miss Rees ' release on 2 1 October and she was released from custody on that day, but the case has still to be heard by a Superior Court. The Australian Embassy has been active in seeking to expedite proceedings.
